author: Thomas D. Dial
post: Family wealth or lack of it is not a valid indicator of capability for college level academic study and is inappropriate, as is family or personal income, for use by a college or university in deciding whether to offer an applicant admission. Both are appropriate in deciding whether to assist a successful applicant financial assistance. The two decisions are not logically related, and attempting to combine them is certain to lead to poor results.
text_s: family wealth lack valid indicator capability college level academic study inappropriate family personal income use college university deciding whether offer applicant admission. appropriate deciding whether assist successful applicant financial assistance. two decisions logically related attempting combine certain lead poor results

author: Miskatonic
post: "Are research papers a waste of time?" Absolutely not! The internet may give students and scholars easy access to sources, but many of these sources are flawed or unreliable in some way. Now more than ever, students need to know how to sift through information to find reliable sources and well-constructed arguments. Writing a research paper is still the best way to do this. Select a paper topic that you find interesting or important. Read and evaluate 10-15 reputable sources related to your topic, and then build an argument that engages with and contributes to this existing research. This might not be the most exciting assignment in the world (depends on the topic, I suppose) but it teaches skills that every college graduate should have. Really, every high school graduate ought to have this training as well. But let's not ask for the moon!

author: Miskatonic
post: "Are research papers a waste of time?" Absolutely not! The internet may give students and scholars easy access to sources, but many of these sources are flawed or unreliable in some way. Now more than ever, students need to know how to sift through information to find reliable sources and well-constructed arguments. Writing a research paper is still the best way to do this. Select a paper topic that you find interesting or important. Read and evaluate 10-15 reputable sources related to your topic, and then build an argument that engages with and contributes to this existing research. This might not be the most exciting assignment in the world (depends on the topic, I suppose) but it teaches skills that every college graduate should have. Really, every high school graduate ought to have this training as well. But let's not ask for the moon!

author: Wyatt
post: I disagree with the above comments and the article. First, the constitutional restraint argument is just ridiculous in the country we live in. Enumerated powers? We started trending away from that when the income tax was passed in what...1916 I think? If we actually practiced anything like constitutional restraint in other areas I would probably buy it but as things stand? No way. As to the childless not getting tax breaks for public schools they don't use because we are all contributing to the next generation... a good argument based on moral principles,but why get all holy all the sudden? The tax code is far from principled. We subsidize homeowners. I am not a homeowner. Not fair. And there is not even a moral argument for that massive tax break. Yet there it is. Why not give something new a chance? The only problem with homeschooling is that it is dominated by right-wing bible-thumpers. If more lefties jumped in the flavor of the whole thing could be changed. For the record I don't have kids and am not religious at all.

author: Matt Nadler
post: We've seen how a wild west approach with no laws works - abused children and adults get exploited. At least with a legal system there are some checks and balances to protect the workers, satisfy demand, and ensure a safe work environment for adults. With a legal path, there's an incentive to play by the rules. Those who continue to operate outside of the laws - the traffickers and child abusers - have less cover from the laws and those who enforce them.
text_s: 've seen wild west approach laws works abused children adults get exploited. least legal system checks balances protect workers satisfy demand ensure safe work environment adults. legal path 's incentive play rules. continue operate outside laws traffickers child abusers less cover laws enforce

author: tigermom
post: I have been successful at both obtaining tenure, academic prestige and children (late, admittedly). The advice I might offer aspiring young women is to find a younger man who is not particularly ambitious or career-focused and who loves kids and homelife. If you find such a man you can reap the same career benefits as your male colleagues who might marry a marriage-minded younger woman. If you want to be successful it is best to pass over the highly decorated, high maintenance males, unless you have decided that kids are not wanted. I also think success and power are attractive to both men and women and that a high status female can find younger partners relatively easily.

author: Bruce Bender
post: Aren't these the same farmers that jump up and down screaming about illegal immigration when the kids want to go to school? The ones that accept huge subsidies from the federal government? My guess is that the ones who are really upset are the large Agribusinesses that use hundreds of illegal laborers at a time. Many small farmers are succeeding with high quality locally raised crops. Here in central Massachusetts, where growing is a real challenge, the small farms are doing very well. Locally raised produce that doesn't need to be transported and stored at tremendous cost is inherently cheaper and better. In the past many solutions to the problem have been proposed, including permits to work temporarily in the US. All defeated. I think some people just like cheap labor and no accountability. Not to worry, though, the migrants are no longer flowing to the US and there are millions of unemployed Americans, so it will work itself out to the benefit of the farmers if we just keep destroying the economy.

author: Rita
post: The author's last sentence actually magpies a strong case for women's colleges. CoEd colleges are not generally "...gender-integrated places, where no one is excluded and both sexes learn how to respect, collaborate with and lead each other through shared experience." This is a nice fantasy but it is not reality. I was fortunate to go to an women's college in a curriculum where male students had to come to our turf. So I had the best of both worlds - the opportunity to study with men but in an environment where women's opinions and observations were honored because it was a women's college. PS. Having just finished "I am Charlotte Simmons" by Tom Wolfe, I think we have made the mistake of thinking that age is the equivalent of the emotional maturity necessary to live together and study together in a mutually beneficial way. If anything, we should have more segregation of the sexes through the college years - not less.

author: Betsy
post: While clearly the Volt is not perfect, I recall a lot of these same issues being brought up when the first hybrids were announced. Too expensive, not worth it, only die-hard environmentalists will buy them and lose money, etc. Yet today look at all the hybrids on the road. And the cost has come down. Is the Volt the answer to our car problems? Of course not. But maybe by starting to realize that gasoline isn't the only way to power a car, it'll lead to hydrogen-powered cars or fuel cells or who knows maybe a technology that doesn't even exist yet. More options are always better!

author: Oakbranch
post: The issue is not whether refugees are good people or not -- rather the concern should be that those fleeing war in Syria should not all be going to Europe. A greater effort needs to be made to keep them in the Middle East, in nations closer to their home, if not indeed in their own country. THe solution to turbulence in Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan, Sudan, or any other nation, is not that these nation's whole populations go to Europe. No nation should be borderless, allowing entry to anyone who walks in. No nation can accomodate an endless number of refugees or immigrants. Nations can and should have workable policies on immigration, capable of being followed and enforced. THis is an issue quite separate from that of terrorism, and one that has been a major political issue in the US for decades already.

author: Michael Gomez
post: When I was a student at Queens College and plans for the first State Lottery were announced, $360 million yearly was the magic number tossed about that would go towards education; many of us there supported the proposition. Prof. Marilyn Gittel posed a rhetorical question ...will the money be in addition to existing funds, or will those funds be reduced by the Lottery revenue? We know the answer to that one, and we also know that promised yields never seem to show up. This is deja vu all over again.

author: Kathleen F.
post: It might be worth taking a look at the CEGEP system in the province of Quebec. In Quebec, High school ends at grade 11. From there, students enter CEGEP which is either two years for students planning on going to university or three years for those in the technical/vocational side. Those who chose the three year program are ready for work right after graduating from CEGEP. The students who are heading to university have had the chance to take courses more focused on their chosen field. Not everyone can or should go to university and the system CEGEP offers an alternative.

author: David
post: I echo the sentiments of others in this thread. As a childless person, it infuriates me to read these arguments. The thought of families getting a $5,000 tax credit -- a payment of $5,000 -- because they don't take advantage of taxpayer-funded schools is outrageous. I pay thousands of dollars a month in taxes for schools that I will never directly take advantage of. Shouldn't I get a tax credit? This philosophy of not paying for public services you don't directly use is poisonous. If you have a huge yard with playground equipment, should you get a tax credit for not using public parks? If you buy books instead of checking them out the library, should you get a tax credit? If you don't have a car and don't use highways, should you get a tax credit? Aside from that, this author's notion that ignoring the Constitution is what got us $14 trillion into debt is ludicrous. A decade of irresponsible tax cuts, two multi-trillion dollar wars and the worst recession of our lifetime has much more to do with it.
text_s: echo sentiments others thread. childless person infuriates read arguments. thought families getting 5,000 tax credit -- payment 5,000 -- n't take advantage taxpayer funded schools outrageous. pay thousands dollars month taxes schools never directly take advantage. n't get tax credit. philosophy paying public services n't directly use poisonous. huge yard playground equipment get tax credit using public parks. buy books instead checking library get tax credit. n't car n't use highways get tax credit. aside author 's notion ignoring constitution got us 14 trillion debt ludicrous. decade irresponsible tax cuts two multi trillion dollar wars worst recession lifetime much

author: tom simkins
post: Who has the time? When the kids are are of school age, the parents - usually both - have their noses to the grindstone. It takes a lot of determination and endurance to sit Junior down for two hours of lessons right after dinner. Further, as degrading as it may seem, schools provide an important function beyond education - as a day care service permitting both parents to be employed. As to the merits of giving tax breaks for home schooling, the public schools are not just going to disappear and their expenses have to be paid. Home schooling certainly means higher taxes.

author: Tracy
post: Declawing prevents cat overpopulation? Doubtful. I was a vet tech prior to becoming an RN. I have been physcially sick twice in the last 10 years of those careers....both times were as a vet tech. Neve as an ER nurse! Once was a shot puppy, another was a post op declaw. It was HORRIBLE. But clearly, sir, you need an anatomy class. You see cats don't reproduce via claws....1 cat can have 30  offspring in the wild.....my cats have the option to go outside (where they were found- cold, starving, wet, fighting for their lives in city streets) they don't want to go outside!!!! Why would they?? And personally I would rather buy 15 couches than live without any of my fur babies. I can't even believe you were allowed to write this article, as you are terribly misinformed.

author: Scotty
post: Perhaps when the Arabs are ready to recognize their own culpability for their situation and stop blaming Israel, the US and Santa Claus for all their problems we might get a resolution to the conflict. When the land was divided between Arabs and Jews in 1948 it was an Arab army which swept into Israel, not an Israeli army which swept into the neighboring Arab countries. Arab Jews were expelled from Arab countries and Palestinians were expelled from Israel. For too long the Arabs have played an all or nothing game. The only peace they want is one with no Jewish State. Calling the entire area Palestine under Arab rule or using the euphemism of a non-denominational democratic Israel (in the Arab world of Islamic Republics?) the goal is the same: The eradication of the Jewish State. Palestinian leadership is so weak and so vulnerable to violent overthrow that they cannot make the tough choices of trading concessions with Israel. Only when there is strong leadership, one voice for the Palestinians, and widespread Palestinian support for trading concessions with Israel can there be peace.

author: John Andrews
post: That's absolutely right! The one-country/one-vote system means that it becomes all too easy to corrupt the voting system by offering inducements/bribes to representatives of poor countries. However, to change the system to favour the developed world cannot be the way to go, neither in the UN nor in FIFA. My preference (hardly ideal, but practical) would be to have a rotation of World Cup venues: Europe, Asia, Africa, the Americas, Middle East. This would not eradicate corruption, but might well limit its scope. And, btw, it would be a very good idea to have term limits on elected FIFA executives. Blatter after Havelange is a sequence that does not inspire confidence.

author: Josh Hill
post: Human males have strong instincts to select mates with good physical attributes. Women therefore seek to compete. The same phenomenon can be observed in insects, birds, and other mammals. Displays of fitness vary, and in some it is the females rather than the males that make the displays. So -- what is wrong with it? The process is comfortably Darwinian and it has contributed to our success as a species. I don't see why political correctness should be allowed to get in the way of that -- not that, in reality, you could argue men out of their attraction to beautiful women anyway.

author: oldgreymare
post: When a couple decides to have children, the children become an integral part of the family and should not be excluded from family adventures unless a child has so severe a disability that he or she cannot go. We rarely took vacations, but when we did it was as a family. Now that our children are grown and all moved away, we seldom see them, so those together times have become even more precious. Children grow up so fast--enjoy them as much as you can. Carve out time for yourselves by enforcing an early bedtime for the offspring.

author: Elaine Bennis
post: Ms. Bedolla's job is to lobby for illegal workers, and this fact makes all of her arguments subject to question. This is standard advocacy talk- the illegal's do the work American's won't do/can't do, and her Georgia example where former convicts, hardly a representative population, were cited as evidence is typical of the distortions practiced by these advoctes. If the farmers want legal workers, then they should pay them a living wage, and Americans should pay the higher resulting prices for the food that they consume .The implication that American's are not hard workers is not borne out by our history.

author: MH
post: The way banks structure their fees for their services is absurd. The free account but profits made through hidden unrelated fees no one expects. It is like grocery stores that offered all their food for free to pull the most possible customers from competitors. But then they charge random cars in the parking lot $100 for parking more than 10 minutes. They charge a $10 surcharge on exit for every child that enters the store (with no signs posted about this on entrance). And an assortment of other fees that change as people catch on. And yet people keep coming for the free food. When the store wants to increase profits it comes up with more absurd fees.

author: Geoff Welborn
post: Thank you! I taught for nine years in Watts at one of the lowest performing schools in Country. The teach for America kids were great but their motives were 'on to bigger and better things' Not one of them stuck around after a year or two. Further, I felt they were treated,more often than not, as warm bodies to fill staffing shortages. Which in and of itself isn't necessarily a bad thing but there appeared, at least in the situation I observed, to be absolutely no support for them once they were in the classroom. It was kind of like dropping somebody into a combat situation with no arms training. In the inner city situation you need more than academics. You need classroom management skills.

author: EarthMom
post: I agree with some of the comments about not pushing kids too young to read and write. However, kids benefit from a preschool environment even if it is all play based. New Zealand has a free preschool program, but the kids don't start learning to read until they enter elementary school and NZ has one of the highest literacy rates in the world. It also benefits those who are in the lower middle class and don't qualify for free programs. This is where we really need to start making a push. So that their kids don't end up in the lower class.

author: gail
post: The push for casinos demonstrates a lack of imagination and forethought of politicians. Casinos are not the wave of the future, they are regressive in every respect. Surely the state senator has a more creative, forward thinking solution to unemployment? Surely the state senator has more respect for his constituents, and will suggest something that elevates his district, bringing them sustainable development that relies on an educated and sophisticated populace, while protecting the cultural and natural resources of that area of NY. author: Dave K
post: "Civilians and even humanitarian workers are afraid to assist victims for fear they may be killed in a second strike." It's worth pointing out that attacking people trying to assist victims in a second strike is a violation of the First Geneva Convention, which the United States has signed. This rule was put in place specifically to prevent the kind of situation where an attack has occurred, medics try to rescue the wounded, and somebody just starts killing medics. That means that anyone ordering those sorts of strikes (which are definitely happening) is a war criminal.

author: truthbetold2
post: The problem is wound up in a simple fact: Division I and probably most of Div II and a lot of Division III institutions serve as (unpaid and unacknowledged) minor league franchises in football and basketball. (That is not the case for baseball.) Academics are secondary. The answer to the dilemma is clear but unlikely: divorce the franchise and the academic operations. Athletes recruited (or volunteering) for either sport should not be expected to enroll for degrees or take classes. They may opt to do so, but must achieve and have access to certain kinds of academic support. Those athletes in either sport who opt not to enroll or who enroll but find they must drop out would be assured places as students for (pick a number of years), beyond the their collegiate playing days. Frankly, I'd prefer simply to force the NFL and the NBA to set up a separate minor league system, as MLB has for many decades. But, given alumni and other pressures, that is unlikely. So, admit the true nature of the relationship (of great advantage to NFL owners) and work around it, without compromising the academic enterprise.
text_s: problem wound simple fact division probably div ii lot division iii institutions serve unpaid unacknowledged minor league franchises football basketball. case baseball. academics secondary. answer dilemma clear unlikely divorce franchise academic operations. athletes recruited volunteering either sport expected enroll degrees take classes. may opt must achieve access certain kinds academic support. athletes either sport opt enroll enroll find must drop would assured places students pick number years beyond collegiate playing days. frankly 'd prefer simply force nfl nba set separate minor league system mlb many decades. given alumni pressures unlikely. admit true nature relationship great advantage nfl owners work around without compromising academic enterprise

author: SB
post: I haven't read through all the comments, but I strongly feel that diet (and what keeps one healthy) is extremely individual and dependent on many things-including allergies, sensitivities, previous medical history, religious experience, and emotional situations, to name a few. I grew up with a father who was a heavy smoker. Possibly as a result, I was given large doses of steroids (to which I became addicted) because I had asthma throughout much of my adolescence. I was also put on thyroid medication for seven years unnecessarily because, at that time, the measures for thyroid were faulty. So today I suffer from osteoporosis and so have adopted a diet rich in calcium. Fortunately, I am not too lactose intolerant and can handle milk products, unless I pick up a virus. I mention all of this to point out that we all have our individual food needs and shouldn't feel compelled to tell others what's good for them.
text_s: n't read comments strongly feel diet keeps one healthy extremely individual dependent many things including allergies sensitivities previous medical history religious experience emotional situations name. grew father heavy smoker. possibly result given large doses steroids became addicted asthma throughout much adolescence. also put thyroid medication seven years unnecessarily time measures thyroid faulty. today suffer osteoporosis adopted diet rich calcium. fortunately lactose intolerant handle milk products unless pick virus. mention point individual food needs n't feel compelled tell others 's good

author: William Scarbrough
post: Having left NYC many years ago, I eventually came to live in a city of 40,000 that through the generosity of a patron secured the talents of the mid 20th century 'starchitects' and prominent firms. Today this small city and its architectural treasures is an international destination for those interested in architecture. Other than the large cities, where else can you find a collection of work by Saarinen, Venturi, Pei, Meier, Polshek, Stern, S.O.M., Pelli, Weese, Gwathmy, Barnes, The Architects Collaborative and sculptors like Henry Moore, Jon Tinguely, Chihuli. Obviously, none were local.

author: Oakbranch
post: The US has been able to identify several US citizens who have traveled to the Middle East to train with violent fanatics, and/or who view websites associated with Daesh or Al Queda, and in this way, some very serious violence has been prevented. European nations can use the same intelligence methods to identify European nationals who do likewise. Effective intelligence is more readily attained, than is the change of an entire culture such that we have fewer young males growing up bored and angry.

author: AG
post: "Casino taxes and development revenue from the city's three casinos generate about $11 million a month for Detroit." And where does this revenue come from? Thin air? The writer has to know this is a negative sum game, not even a zero sum game. For every dollar the city takes in, you can be sure the casino operators take at least five. The people who spend this money are overwhelmingly those who can't afford it, so that the 11 million they get back in services is less than what they lost in the first place. At the end of the day, the casino ends up making no new product, or service, other than escapist entertainment. But, but, but, you say, the casino puts the money back in the community. I bet. See the piece by Professor Simon on Atlantic City. Maybe the money does come out of thin air -- Canadians and non-Detroiters. Well that's great. Here you go, Paul. Sorry, Peter.

author: Daisy Sue
post: As a feminist, and a mom of a boy and a girl, I want equal opportunity for both of them. I would love to find a college beyond Wabash that's all male. Because: on average boys are doing poorly in school compared with girls. It would be even better if that all-male school encouraged the arts--everything from fine arts to domestic arts, animal husbandry, and gardening, in addition to a rigorous curriculum of reading, writing, arithmetic, and science.

author: NotJamesMadison
post: Isn't federalism wonderful. States can be laboratories for democracy, ... except when they do something judged inappropriate. Can we expect Roger Clegg and his friends to take up the fight to deny felons the votes in Maine and Vermont, which do not disenfranchise their felons at all, or in the states that re-enfranchise their felon on release from prison. More importantly, it's time to ensure that the census counts incarcerated felons at their place of last residence rather than their prison? Counting the incarcerated at their prisons boosts the legislative representation of the prison areas at the expense of the prisoners' real neighborhoods.

author: LETFREEDOMRING2
post: Not all who study law want to practice law. They may want to get into business fields where the law degree and some knowledge is helpful. Many students not adept at test taking make wonderful lawyers, not for research perhaps but as litigators. Law Exams in California go for three days and they are very tough but the best top schools have high percentages passing as they take Bar Review courses for a month or so before the actual three day grind. Only graduates from the top law schools with the best grades get the jobs with the giant law firms if that is what you crave you better have passed the bar the first time out. Passing the bar takes hard study and determination. The Law is not a profession for sissies.

author: Sandra
post: We are a stupid species. We have known cures right in front of us. Cures for some of the deadliest diseases, and what do we do? We invite them back by not vaccinating our children. It's not the disease that will wipe out us in the end, but our own ignorance.

author: MB
post: There is a similar system in the UK. All children aged 3 and upwards are entitled to 15 hours of preschool / nursery per week. This ensures that children are well-socialized and exposed to group environments before they start school, which is at the age of 4 / turning 5 in the UK. Another option for the US would be to just lower the school starting age. In my state, California, the cut-off date for children starting kindergarten is September 1st. As my son's birthday is in October, this means he will be almost 6 years old before he is in any kind of group learning or social environment (unless we decide to put him preschool of course). Why not lower the kindergarten age by a year instead of starting a preschool program? The sooner children learn to deal with a group environment and the joy of learning, the better.
text_s: similar system uk. children aged 3 upwards entitled 15 hours preschool nursery per week. ensures children well socialized exposed group environments start school age 4 turning 5 uk. another option us would lower school starting age. state california cut date children starting kindergarten september 1st. son 's birthday october means almost 6 years old kind group learning social environment unless decide put preschool course. lower kindergarten age year instead starting preschool program. sooner children learn deal group environment joy learning better

author: Jubilee133
post: 'The nuclear deal also opens unprecedented communication channels between Iran and the United States that may prevent future crises, just as we witnessed with the recent prisoner swap and Tehran's speedy release of detained American sailors.' Thank you. I needed a quick laugh. Our sailors were captured prior to sanctions being lifted, and were not returned until the sanctions were almost lifted, and a 1.7 billion dollar jizya, Islamic tax, was paid for our hostages. Again. Thee was no "speedy diplomacy," or really any kind of rapprochement. The Iranian regime, unlike the Arab Spring, has not moved an iota since 1979. Except that in 10 years, they will have a bomb to fit onto their ICBMs. That will certainly be new. But the answer to this "debate" is: "Are your children, grandchildren, sleeping in Tel Aviv tonight?" if not, the Iranians look less threatening today. If yes, then you see the truth very clearly.

author: kamaridurley
post: Allowing foreign airlines to serve domestic routes is definitely something that doesn't get brought up enough. It's funny how the domestic carriers are all for deregulation and increased competition in theory, but once outside foreign airlines are involved, they rely on what you rightfully point out is antiquated regulation. Fact is that Americans really only have a choice between four airlines for domestic travel and are subject to the whims of these companies. The airline industry is a monopolistic entity and should be treated as such. This means to be required to cooperate with certain regulations.

author: RT
post: Avital says "... let's start with the basics. Any nation wishing to declare independence should meet three essential elements: a strong central government, control of defined territory and security. ". Well we could also start with some basics about the legitimacy of a government to govern people under its control. Without expounding broadly, any basic set of rights would lead to changes in the West Bank and Gaza; and maybe within Israel itself. Israel needs to grant more autonomy, stop creating more settlements, and accept the fact there will be violent acts for decades; let's "get a move on". The status quo is not working.

author: Pierce Randall
post: "[T]here were 1.5 million fewer native-born Americans working than in November 2007, while 2 million more immigrants (legal and illegal) were working. Thus, all net employment gains since November 2007 have gone to immigrants." That's a woefully fallacious inference. What's a "net employment gain"? You can't have a gain without an idea of a baseline--what is the relevant level against which we say that we have gained jobs? We have no idea what the jobs situation would be like without those 2 million immigrants; it could be that without those immigrants buying goods and services, we would have even less employment for non-immgrant workers. This kind of argument commits the fixed pie fallacy. It assumes that there's some fixed amount of low-skilled jobs that will exist anyway, and every job an immigrant takes is one a non-immigrant low-skilled worker loses. But that's obviously not how the economy works.
text_s: t]here 1.5 million fewer native born americans working november 2007 2 million immigrants legal illegal working. thus net employment gains since november 2007 gone immigrants. 's woefully fallacious inference. 's net employment gain. ca n't gain without idea baseline -- relevant level say gained jobs. idea jobs situation would like without 2 million immigrants could without immigrants buying goods services would even less employment non immgrant workers. kind argument commits fixed pie fallacy. assumes 's fixed amount low skilled jobs exist anyway every job immigrant takes one non immigrant low skilled worker loses. 's obviously economy works

author: Great White North Guy
post: While it is true that the USA does not actively discourage dual citizenship, it does so by taxing its citizens who are making their lives abroad based on citizenship rather than country of permanent residence. Trust me, this is discouraging dual citizenship and encouraging people to take on another and drop their US citizenship. Many of you will say that this is the cost of membership!! It just happens that after living in several other countries, many of us realize that the USA is not a club we want to be part of. So yes, we give up our citizenship. Good riddance you might say? Fine, but who do you think is loosing the most, the skilled expat workers and professionals who make a conscious decision to abandon their citizenship and are in demand around the word or the US? As an aside, the USA is only one of two countries in the world to double tax its non-resident citizens... the other is Eretrya, a small country in the horn of Africa ruled by one of the most brutal dictatorships in the world.

author: Edmund Dantes
post: What bunk. The worst dietary info we've gotten has been from the USDA! There's a very simple cure for the obesity epidemic. Stop subsidizing food. Americans spend far, far less of the income on food than those in other nations. End the farm subsidies. End the food stamp subsidies. Stop interfering with market mechanisms. The price of food will rise, as it should, and the obesity epidemic will slowly become a memory. The nanny state mentality is the source of most problems in this country.

author: Navigator
post: I am surprised by the naivete of many commenters and even some contributors. The business of NY is real estate and the banks that finance it. Much like the business of Washington is government and the business of Las Vegas is gambling. Real Estate taxes and the revenues that come from the construction of new buildings is the lifeblood of the city. It has been that way for at least two hundred years. Ours is not a national capital like London, Paris, or Berlin. We are a business city and have to generate as well as spend money. NY has been very good at both things for many decades. The idea that somehow real estate interests are out of control or taking over how the city is run is perhaps news for 1815, not 2015. Without the millionaires and billionaires building and buying these fancy new places, New York would be Philadelphia. Philadelphia is a lovely place and if you prefer it, you should seriously consider moving there because NY is never going to be Philadelphia.

author: Samantha
post: I'm sick of proponents glorifying the benefits of outsourcing because Americans have lost their jobs, thanks to lobbyists, political leanings and Wall Streets' focus on the bottom line. There is a correlation between our high unemployment rate and outsourcing. Off-shoring is the appropriate word but when you are one of the millions whose job is gone, off-shoring and outsourcing mean the same thing: no job. The biggest fear now is that when Tea Partiers and Republicans finish taking the government apart with the rataionale of getting spending under control, unemployment may be higher. Because outsourcing has the mantra of cheapest and lowest cost, our neighbors and children pay the cost. The wages paid in India, China, Brazil are not enough to support American lifestyles, communities and housing. Having seen the devastation that outsourcing has done to communities I've traveled to, I no longer support it. The devastating cost has long outweighed the benefits.

author: Leon
post: The author is correct to observe that "...racial disparities remain alarmingly wide." But there is no evidence to suggest that affirmative action can change that. Affirmative action is quite likely part of the problem, not the solution. It insults blacks and hispanics and breeds resentment in others. Let's stop discriminating against people because of their skin color and let's increase opportunity for everyone in our society, especially for those at the bottom of the economy.

author: CB
post: The average teacher may have one at most two classes on children's or young adult literature. Many that I have met have an extremely shallow knowledge of this category of learning. In contrast librarians have a tremendous base of knowledge that guides not just students but the teachers within a school. Beyond the love books and knowledge librarians empower students to go beyond google, they help students learn differentiate and validate information in the sea of misinformation that characterizes the internet today. Yes teachers and schools can stumble on without a librarian, but it is as if we would ask a child to each McDonalds for a meal everyday. Their education is ultimately nutrient diminished.

author: frustrated with smartphones
post: I am a 20-year-old female college student who does not own a smart phone and does not wish to own one. I feel as though I am one of the few left of my age (and in general) who have not been sucked into the smartphone (mostly iphone) world. It can be very frustrating for me when my friends are constantly glued to their devices. I often find myself in social situations where everyone in the room are on their phones and I am left sitting, waiting for someone to come back into the real world in order to have a conversation or to decide on something to do other than stare at a screen. In this sense I agree that smartphones/facebook can be potentially damaging to relationships or at least to proper social conduct.

author: Marco Scalvini
post: I personally think that using arguments and evidence is central in any debate. However the nature of research changed with the advent of databases and google. Moreover the Internet has dramatically changed the way people discuss or just get information about public issues. Perhaps, it would be more helpful to teach students how to deal with digital tools more consciously. For example, when I was a TA, my supervisor gave to his undergraduate students a very original assignment: writing a wikipedia entry. Writing a Wikipedia article seems a simple task, it is a very challenging work because first of all it is an hypertext and references, quotations, link are central to prove both the entry is verifiable and well structured. Second, editors review all articles that are submitted and there is a group approval system to determine if content is published, or rejected in the case of plagiarism or poor quality.
text_s: personally think using arguments evidence central debate. however nature research changed advent databases google. moreover internet dramatically changed way people discuss get information public issues. perhaps would helpful teach students deal digital tools consciously. example ta supervisor gave undergraduate students original assignment writing wikipedia entry. writing wikipedia article seems simple task challenging work first hypertext references quotations link central prove entry verifiable well structured. second editors review articles submitted group approval system determine content published rejected case plagiarism poor quality

author: Andrew Gillis
post: On my flight yesterday from Seattle to Dulles/DC the legroom upgrade would have been $119, not $39. Where I live, Southwest doesn't fly, so that isn't happening. Because flying has become so unpleasant I do it as little as possible. The only bright spot is the foreign carriers on trans Atlantic flights--a trip to Milan via Emirates last summer was a pleasure, with legroom, edible food and a choice of 500 movies to watch for free. Regulation of things like legroom and full disclosure of fees sounds like a good idea to me.

author: oxfordon
post: I am surprised that the Times should give this crackpot idea so much space. Capital gains is the income of the rich. Are the rich supposed to be exempt from taxation? They depend on society to produce their riches. In late-Victorian Britain, the argument was the opposite. Non-work income was 'unearned income' and was taxed at a higher rate. And spare us the argument that low taxes on capital gains promotes economic growth. Under low capital gains tax (since the 1980s) growth was slower than in the post-war periods, when taxes were high. And virtually all the benefits of growth have gone to the rich.
text_s: surprised times give crackpot idea much space. capital gains income rich. rich supposed exempt taxation. depend society produce riches. late victorian britain argument opposite. non work income unearned income taxed higher rate. spare us argument low taxes capital gains promotes economic growth. low capital gains tax since 1980s growth slower post war periods taxes high. virtually benefits growth gone rich

author: Just a guy
post: Although I have no idea what studies show about home schooled kids, I do know that, having hired two of them, my impression is not favorable. Both were prima donnas who spent a lot of time complaining about work rules, who thought that they should be able to change work processes to suit them, and who resorted to crying and making scenes to try and get their way with co-workers. The public school system was established primarily as a benefit to society, not just the individual child. That is why we all pay taxes to the schools whether we have kids or not. If people want to take their children out, so be it -- but they still still have their obligation to support the schools.

author: Wordsworth from Wadsworth
post: If we just had millions upon billions living in unindustrialized countries or places in which people had no discretionary income to participate in a consumer society, Erhlich would have remained wrong. But societies around the globe have changed, and everyone desires a higher standard of living. Now Erhlich is right. Okay, let's make an effort to reduce consumption. But does not our economy and our whole way of life rest on the foundation of a consumer society? Without the populace subscribing to and participating in a society dedicated to making or marketing things and buying them, how do we structure society then? What do people do in lieu of buying stuff? How is power accorded and meted out? How do people obtain the necessities? How do they generate income? I would suggest that there is more to the challenge than "to fix capitalism by encouraging innovation in the technologies that can deliver a liveable world. " There will have to be a philosophy with which to address nature and the universe, for both the powers-that-be and hoi polloi.
text_s: millions upon billions living unindustrialized countries places people discretionary income participate consumer society erhlich would remained wrong. societies around globe changed everyone desires higher standard living. erhlich right. okay let 's make effort reduce consumption. economy whole way life rest foundation consumer society. without populace subscribing participating society dedicated making marketing things buying structure society. people lieu buying stuff. power accorded meted. people obtain necessities. generate income. would suggest challenge fix capitalism encouraging innovation technologies deliver liveable world. philosophy address nature universe powers hoi polloi

author: Ed
post: . Do alcohol and marijuana affect some users negatively? Absolutely. Should minors be allowed to legally consume either one? No. But the war on drugs is a failure. But making them illegal protects no one.

author: george
post: An experience similar to Ms. Jackson's at CVS highlighted the degeneration of mathematical facility in young people. My bill at a fast food restaurant came to $10.15 and I handed the young lady behind the register $20.15. She looked at the 15 cents and at me all puzzled; she shuffled it around the counter. Then she entered $20.15 into the register and when it showed that the change due was $10.00 her face lit up. The mystery puzzle was solved. She looked at me with an awe that reflected her amazement that I could think of this ingenious gambit. Needless to say I was also amazed. I am similary awed when I read of surveys wherein significant numbers of college students (even in Southern California) could not identify a country that borders the U.S. or did not know which side the U.S. fought on in WWII.
text_s: experience similar ms. jackson 's cvs highlighted degeneration mathematical facility young people. bill fast food restaurant came 10.15 handed young lady behind register 20.15. looked 15 cents puzzled shuffled around counter. entered 20.15 register showed change due 10.00 face lit. mystery puzzle solved. looked awe reflected amazement could think ingenious gambit. needless say also amazed. similary awed read surveys wherein significant numbers college students even southern california could identify country borders u.s. know side u.s. fought wwii

author: Eugene
post: In today's Western world, almost all children survive to adulthood, thanks to good medical care, no wars, and a much better standard of living. In this scenario, there's no real need to have lots of children, parents can just have 1 (let's say) and be reasonably certain that that child will have a normal life. If it's OK to have just one child, then women feel that they don't need to start early. A woman in her late 30s can still bear that one child, so delayed motherhood makes perfect sense. In the past, women started early because they planned several children, and that in turn was caused by high mortality.

author: James Watt
post: the title, "It's as American as Apple pie" is childish. It's as if 'smoking is American in 1960 and thus a good thing.' The whole system is broken. Tips range all over the place....Restaurants in America should learn to global system of paying standard wages and tipping should be just a minor thank you. Use to be 10 -15% was a good tip. Now it's 20-30%. Soon it will be considered declasse to tip less then 50%. Wake up and smell the inequity.

post: I think they can be quite normal..Prince Edward and Sophie lead a fairly normal life..although, of course, he is not in line for the throne. And Kate and William have known each other for 8 years..and there does not seem to be a "Camila" lurking in his background..with their life under a microscope, we would know! author: WimR
post: Claiming that Assad and ISIS are both evil suggest a moral equivalence that is unjustified. Assad uses horrible means to stay in power but we should not forget that before the trouble started he was quite popular and many assume that he might win free elections. Daily life in peace under ISIS is fundamentally more troublesome. The trouble with expanding attacks on ISIS to Syria is that it gives Washington a role in the Syrian conflict. We may also see that once Washington starts bombing them many ISIS members will start to call themselves members of Al Nusra or some other Syrian rebel group. In my opinion the only way to go forward is to strive for an agreement between Assad and the moderate opposition. Until now the US has sabotaged such negotiations and supported those rebels who don't want to compromise. But if Washington gets serious about negotiations and presses the other countries supporting the rebels to get similarly serious some compromise should be possible.

author: Casual Observer
post: People who are in the habit of behaving with civility tend not to commit minor crimes and to not disrespect the lives of others. Police work that enforces minor offenses and quality of life ordinances sends the message that uncivil behavior will not be tolerated. Some in poorly policed areas are characterized by a lot of people who live in distress, are exposed to criminal behavior on a daily basis, and are exposed to significant numbers of people who are used to acting out without any consequences. In such areas the worst behaving people end up determining the living conditions of all.

author: dhinnah
post: First, the result of farm subsidies is cheaper food, not rich farmers. Second, farm subsidies should be reduced to help reduce the deficit, but that reduction should be proportional. Elimination of farm subsidies would dramatically affect our balance of trade, as farm exports currently help balance imports of manufactured goods.

author: jb
post: In my state, the guards at the gates of a major Air Force base were privatized! A security company took over, despite thousands of soldiers on base. At least until the man who owned the security guard company took off one day without paying the guards. And that's just one case. In nearly every instance where knee-jerk privatizers take over, the workers lose pay and benefits, a few owners rake in our tax money, and services sink to the bottom of a deep, dark pit. In Afghanistan and Iraq, Halliburton et al. rake in billions year after year, take the lion's share, and then farm out the work to sub-sub-sub contractors, who get pennies on the dollar and do a cheap, ineffective job--if it's done at all. And no one in power complains. When do we stop the madness?

author: Joseph Ross Mahew
post: I'm beginning to see that up here in Soviet Kanukistan, we have it REALLY cushy when it comes to the banking industry. There is open, honest competition between banks for the customer's business, for one thing: not apparent collusion between major banks to charge similar fees and stifle true competition!! I pay $8.5 per month, get free debit services, free checking, 10 ATM transactions per month, and my overdraft fees are only $5 per shot (thank goodness, lol!!). Most ATMs charge $1.5 for transactions not associated with their sponsoring banks and even the private ones only ask this much. I remember visiting the USA in 1998 and simply refusing to pay $3 just to use an ATM!!!! The USA is the richest country on the planet, with the hugest bank profits... looks like exploiting the poor and vulnerable in their society is one of the ways they GOT so rich in the first place.

author: Greystone
post: As another commentator mentioned, the widespread use of cell phone cameras and convenient connectivity of the Internet make it easy to catch and publicize celebrities living their lives. In the old days, photography required a large bulky camera, a big flash gun, and time to set up the camera. Today's cell phones take a reasonable-quality photo instantly. Actors and sports figures are not public policy makers. As opposed to public government officials (elected or appointed), celebrities do not decide how much taxes we pay, what laws we must observe, or whether we go to war. As such, they should be give more privacy. In other words, it may be in the public interest to publicize a congressman patronizing a brothel, especially when that congressman takes a high moralistic political position. When an actor or sports figure (or a retired out-of-office politician for that matter) does such a thing, it doesn't affect the rest of us and isn't really a matter of the public interest. Of course, some celebrities like the publicity and generate it themselves. They feel compelled to announce (and the media feels compelled to publish) when they start a new relationship or terminate one.
text_s: another commentator mentioned widespread use cell phone cameras convenient connectivity internet make easy catch publicize celebrities living lives. old days photography required large bulky camera big flash gun time set camera. today 's cell phones take reasonable quality photo instantly. actors sports figures public policy makers. opposed public government officials elected appointed celebrities decide much taxes pay laws must observe whether go war. give privacy. words may public interest publicize congressman patronizing brothel especially congressman takes high moralistic political position. actor sports figure retired office politician matter thing n't affect rest us n't really matter public interest. course celebrities like publicity generate. feel compelled announce media feels compelled publish start new relationship terminate one

author: Patrick
post: My wife and I are long-time vegans raising a healthy vegan child. Our wonderful daughter is above-average in height and in the 95th percentile in head size. She has hit virtually every developmental milestone at least a month ahead of average, and she has been regularly declared healthy and above average by our pediatrician, who has decades of experience with thousands of children and who has declared that he is comfortable with our vegan choice. We know at least a dozen other vegan children who are healthy and high-functioning. That's consistent with the findings of the American Dietetic Association, the nation's largest organization of nutrition scientists, which has issued a position paper written by experts who reviewed the existing peer-reviewed literature and found that well-planned vegan diets are healthful for infants and children. The considered opinion of such experts--and of our pediatrician--are what we rely on to make decisions about our child. We don't tend to factor in the opinions of cookbook writers.

author: Pooja
post: When a hurricane hits and the beaches are damaged, it is the tax payer who pays to have the beaches restored. Why do beach house owners believe they can cut off access to a beach when it is the tax payers who pay to maintain it? If they refuse to allow access to the beach, and the local police departments ticket & tow cars parked on the street owned by out of towners using the beach, then the government should exercise eminent domain, kick the owners to the curb and raze the houses. The beach and the ocean belong to everyone, and everyone should have full and free access. FREE access. Don't get me started on towns that have the nerve to charge a fee to allow people the privilege of sticking their toes in the sand. That is absurd, too.

author: EC
post: What the NJ Transit employee failed to understand is that there is a distinction between free speech rights (burning a Koran, a flag or what have you) and the fact that employment in America is, by and large, at-will -- you can get fired if your boss doesn't like the color of your socks. If his off-hours -- but very public and very controversial -- actions were deemed to affect his workplace efficiency, then his employer had a perfect right to fire him. Sadly, this particular individual has learned, in the harshest way possible, a rule of Free Speech that many tend to forget in our times: just because you have the right to say whatever you want it doesn't mean that it's always a smart idea to do so.
text_s: nj transit employee failed understand distinction free speech rights burning koran flag fact employment america large -- get fired boss n't like color socks. hours -- public controversial -- actions deemed affect workplace efficiency employer perfect right fire. sadly particular individual learned harshest way possible rule free speech many tend forget times right say whatever want n't mean 's always smart idea

post: Most of the smartest women I know aren't competing in pageants...and the opportunities these pageants provide in cash for a few women do not undue the harm that they cause for the millions of others that watch. author: fedup
post: The money spent on intercollegiate athletics could be better spent. How much of college fees go directly to athletics in which a small percentage of students participate? My daughter has a PhD and teaches at a state university with great athletics. She makes less than $45,000 a year although instructors have gone through an arbitration process. The school refuses to go along with the decision reached (for five years - wages frozen). With so many colleges not hiring, she considers herself lucky to have a job. And yet, the athletic department is not sharing the pain. It is time to recommit to the purpose of higher education. I am assuming here that it is not to teach football. If it is, then they should be paying tuition not getting athletic scholarships.

author: A Guy
post: It has nothing to do with nutrition education. Nowadays, we have this magical thing called the internet. There are no excuses for not knowing what's healthy and what isn't. You're either too lazy to figure it out for yourself (and so you let the food companies tell you what to eat -- nice conflict of interest right there), or you simply don't care. I also like how you mention ridiculous "documented" results yet fail to provide said documents. A "50% reduction in the incidence of children becoming overweight." You can deduce that just by changing drinks in a vending machine? Please tell what analysis was performed to come to that fitting conclusion -- as a statistician, I'd love to know. And, Yael, "100% juice" isn't any better than soda. It's all garbage.

author: Adam
post: I strongly disagree with the author's characterization of prostitution, but strongly agree with the author's suggestion of what to do about it. Prostitutes are most certainly allowed to say no to unwanted sex. It is only because the current system within which prostitution operates has so disempowered prostitutes -- leaving them vulnerable to both their clients, their employers, and the law -- that their wishes are so easily disregarded. If the prostitution laws were reversed so that it is the johns and the pimps, not the prostitutes, who commit the crime, then prostitutes would have much greater power to avoid unwanted sexual contact and violence, and perhaps a much better chance of getting out of the business altogether.

author: Bob
post: I have taught at elite universities for the past 43 years. Before that, I served three years as an enlisted man in the United States Army and taught arithmetic to students in surveying students at the engineer school at Ft. Belvior. From this limited experience, I can make two observations. Students at elite universities have grown stronger in the last four decades and the state of American secondary education in 1964 was awful. Enlisted men who had had be selected to learn surveying had mathematic skills that were so weak we did not try to teach lowest common denominator when we covered fractions. I don't think we are getting dumber and we still have a system that can discover talent in students from less privileged backgrounds. The present state of political discourse is discouraging, but in the past we have had Senator McCarthy and his list of communists in the State Department, the hysteria leading to the Spanish-American War, the American Civil War and a very long list of disturbing events in Europe from the Holocaust to the Crusades. Be cheerful. It has always been this good or this bad.
text_s: taught elite universities past 43 years. served three years enlisted man united states army taught arithmetic students surveying students engineer school ft belvior. limited experience make two observations. students elite universities grown stronger last four decades state american secondary education 1964 awful. enlisted men selected learn surveying mathematic skills weak try teach lowest common denominator covered fractions. n't think getting dumber still system discover talent students less privileged backgrounds. present state political discourse discouraging past senator mccarthy list communists state department hysteria leading spanish american war american civil war long list disturbing events europe holocaust crusades. cheerful. always good bad

author: Megaculpa
post: If tips motivate servers, then why is service generally better in Europe than in the US? The answer is because in Europe, restaurant staff are treated like professionals and they respond accordingly. They receive decent wages and benefits, are properly trained and take pride in doing a good job. American wait staff tend to be young people, filling time until something better comes along. Their obsequious desire to please doesn't make up for being overworked and improperly trained. Tipping just props up a bad system.

author: Dr. Ebbyguru
post: As a prof for 34 years, people ask me whether students are getting dumber or smarter. That would be very hard to quantify even with the most sophisticated measurement instruments. Empirically (that means observations done more or less scientifically) I see that there are still those that have it (intelligence, critical reasoning, a thirst for readiing, cognitive complexity) and those who don't (or just don't care). Additionally, most of us profs notice that there is a huge gap between those haves and have nots and that there is a huge gulf of mediocrity in our young people and citizenry. Unless you count ability to distinguish between Manolo and Jimmy Choo shoes, we are definitely becoming dumber. But remember, most of our empiricism is done at the local tavern.

author: Joe
post: I should not be surprised at the high level of naive, inaccurate and incorrect comments. Some of these readers need to research about what they believe about electric cars. Some misconceptions are that batteries don't last that long (they do and are easily recyclable), biodiesel is a viable fuel source of trans fuel for the planet (will not hardly make a dent in demand), fuel cells technology is possible soon (long way off), environmentalists are responsible for keeping diesel cars out of the USA (VW is selling them and the EPA is responsible for clean air.) Electric costs will go up. (A larger percentage of charging will be in off-peak hours making power companies more efficient since they have to power up and down every night and incentives to build more efficient and alternative generation.) Or for no other reason, it's just plain stupid to make an electric car. (Don't buy one then.)

author: edburgess
post: The single most important issue is 'portion size'. People don't need to change how they cook as much as they need to change how much they cook. My son gained weight when he left home, but when he lost 50 lbs with the help of a diet sold by a national franchiser, he realised that the amount of food that he was served at home (and complained about) was a normal portion size. Now he is much more thoughtful about what food he orders, even from the fast food chains. Try searching on the term "portion distortion' and look at the 2 powerpoint presentations from the NIH. They are very useful in teaching patients about what to eat and how active you must be if you eat the large portions that are sold.

author: mkb
post: Cloth, regardless of what colors it is dyed, is just cloth. Paper, regardless of what is printed on it, is just paper. author: Terrence
post: "Ask teachers who have been at it for a decade or more if they were better in their first year or their tenth. The resounding answer -- at least from those who love teaching -- will be that their years of experience made them so much better that they often feel sorry for the kids who were in their class that first year." Of course, one might ask for some data in lieu of the directive to the reader to conduct a survey, but perhaps more glaring is the assumption that the "experienced" teachers are in a position to know. Are they disinterested so as to be in a position to judge? Isn't their response likely to be purely subjective? Formerly a college professor, I rarely have met a high school teacher who I thought was sufficiently educated in his or her subject to be teaching it. I would say a masters degree in the field doesn't cut it, certainly not at the high school level, and a degree in "Education," of any sort, from BA to PhD, definitely doesn't qualify anyone to teach at any level, from kindergarten to graduate school.

author: Terrence
post: "Ask teachers who have been at it for a decade or more if they were better in their first year or their tenth. The resounding answer -- at least from those who love teaching -- will be that their years of experience made them so much better that they often feel sorry for the kids who were in their class that first year." Of course, one might ask for some data in lieu of the directive to the reader to conduct a survey, but perhaps more glaring is the assumption that the "experienced" teachers are in a position to know. Are they disinterested so as to be in a position to judge? Isn't their response likely to be purely subjective? author: Michelle
post: Yes, we have "a generation of illiterates and dumbells..." I have to attempt to teach them. They aren't illiterate because the school system is broken, they are lazy, pampered, and spoiled--at home. Do they really expect a teacher to create a different lesson for kids because the parents don't like the content? When are they going to do this, before or after they create lessons for all of the special ed kids that that the law says must be "mainstreamed" into classes that are over their heads? When they are creating science lessons that must incorporate math, reading, arts, and practical living? What are the other students going to do while the teacher is teaching all of this alternative material? I WISH more parents had a clue what was going on in the school, but they need to work with the system, not against it. Like the author, if my parent didn't want me to hear, see, or do what what was going on in class, I left the room, went to the library, etc. We need to get over claiming our "rights" and pay attention to what is really important to society.

author: northlander
post: Bove ignores a major factor in largeness, the direction of capital away from productive investment and into speculation. The justification of profitability as a sole measure is a basic one for consolidating banks, but with that consolidation comes direction of capital away from production and into speculative instruments. Irresponsibility came from engineering returns rather than earning them. Failure came from a quantitative analysis of investment options that valued high investment risk over productive risk.In a smaller institution this would have simply constituted fraud. In these behemoths it constitutes lingering catastrophe. We still have not freed capital from these casino operators. We who supply them with deposits and tax buffers are denied a flow of funds in interest or investment than support or employ. Flush them into a banking system that buys us jobs, not chips.
text_s: bove ignores major factor largeness direction capital away productive investment speculation. justification profitability sole measure basic one consolidating banks consolidation comes direction capital away production speculative instruments. irresponsibility came engineering returns rather earning. failure came quantitative analysis investment options valued high investment risk productive risk smaller institution would simply constituted fraud. behemoths constitutes lingering catastrophe. still freed capital casino operators. supply deposits tax buffers denied flow funds interest investment support employ. flush banking system buys us jobs chips

author: Goose
post: As a former Principal of a large public high school I am appalled at what I've read re the holding back of the female student. While she might not have been my favorite visitor to my office due to some of her behaviors (Which seem quite innocuous by the way), holding her back a year only acts as an incentive to others to toe the school's rather arcane method of enforcing an Orwellian form of discipline and thought control. Should she remain at the school, my impression is that she will either act out more aggressively to these absurd rules, or capitulate and become a drone-like student. If this is Educational theory, we are in deep trouble

author: Patricia
post: " Suffice it to say that the reinstitution of happy hour, with its drunken hordes stumbling forth onto Illinois' roads, is not likely to make Illinois' roads safer." I am against drunk driving, and I think alcohol is a truly rotten drug. But it does not "suffice to say" that reinstating happy hour will make the roads less safe. Laws that protect public safety have to be based on actual data. Not on the moral projections we think are obvious in our heads.

author: slavicdiva
post: We've given tax breaks to the wealthy for 30 years now, and the economic benefits that were supposed to have flowed from such breaks have not materialized. So how about something new? Eliminate taxes on wages and salaries, and raise them on capital gains. Then the people who actually buy the goods and services produced by businesses will have the money to plow back into the economy. The rising tide of workers should then lift all the boats of the capitalists, no?
text_s: 've given tax breaks wealthy 30 years economic benefits supposed flowed breaks materialized. something new. eliminate taxes wages salaries raise capital gains. people actually buy goods services produced businesses money plow back economy. rising tide workers lift boats capitalists

author: tizzielish
post: This comment is a bit dumb in its limited focus. The guy says kids don't need to be taught how to search the internet, as if everything that is available in a library, esp. a research library, can be found on an internet search engine. Not true. There are all kinds of databases with densely packed data that require expertise to access. Helping students find their way through increasingly modern archives of value treasure troves of data is what librarians do. Maybe fifth graders don't all need to do high level research but we need some humans prepared to do serious, in-depth research in the human future. Doesn't that effort begin in school? It is mindboggling me that this 'expert', a high-tech exec in Silicon Valley (as if that means he knows anything about research) who actually participated on a board that established CA educational standards. It's scary to have such a lame-brained mind in such a position of power over educational standards for CA children. I have a doctorate and sometimes I need a librarian to help me find answers to questions. That's what librarians are for. And kids need them more than I do.

author: Truth
post: Given that even species that are 100% herbivores feed their young milk (cows, for example), doesn't it stand to reason that human infants should not be vegan during their development? I am a vegetarian that eats eggs, and I strongly support vegetarianism/veganism for adults. But for kids, especially infants, it seems too risky to force on them a vegan diet. You only get one chance to do infancy right.

author: Jim
post: To say that most teachers look back at their first years of teaching with regrets is an understatement. As a teacher for 22 years, I can attest to the effort it takes to gain competence and mastery. After years of reflection, feedback, more reflection and refinement of techniques, I am proud of the product given to my wonderful middle school math students. And many people would have said I was pretty good 22 years ago. Would you rather use an automobile mechanic who is untested or the tried and true pro?

author: William Case
post: The Texas "Top 10% Plan, which guarantees admission to any student who finishes in the top 10 of his or her graduation class, works best. Under the old system, which was based on race and ethnicity, middle- and upper-income Hispanics got all the acceptance letters. Now that the 10% rule in in effect, Hispanic students from the barrio schools are, for the first time, getting acceptance letters. The income-based plan won't work because low-income white students academically outperform low- and lower-middle income Hispanic students.
text_s: texas top 10 plan guarantees admission student finishes top 10 graduation class works best. old system based race ethnicity middle- upper income hispanics got acceptance letters. 10 rule effect hispanic students barrio schools first time getting acceptance letters. income based plan wo n't work low income white students academically outperform low- lower middle income hispanic students

author: R. Adelman
post: I've never understood why I, the customer, should have to pay the salaries of restaurant employees. They have an employer. I'm not their employer. I'm the customer. Where else but in a restaurant does the customer directly pay the salary of the worker? It's bizarre. In fact, some restaurant employees are the employees of very wealthy employers, who can well afford to pay them, but sit instead somewhere and chuckle at the good fortune of not having to pay their employees but a pittance because the customers, those suckers, are picking up the tab.

author: madrona
post: During my career as a college administrator I interviewed my fair share of obese job applicants for professional positions. Regardless of their intellect or job experience, there was no chance of their being hired. Why? Because they couldn't fit in the chairs at the conference table where search committees met. They sat on the edge of chairs and almost fell forward trying to balance, which didn't do much for their concentrating on complex question from faculty members. They were constantly out of breath, and sweating, and struggled to reach for the glass of water set before them. They could barely walk to various sites around campus for a required tour, and in some cases, wouldn't even try. They shuffled down the halls while their fit escorts waited, if not patiently, certainly politely. Faculty and other professional jobs require energy and stamina. No amount of intellect can overcome these kinds of self-induced problems, and discrimination is really irrelevant in such cases when one considers the terrible burden such people impose on employers.
text_s: career college administrator interviewed fair share obese job applicants professional positions. regardless intellect job experience chance hired. could n't fit chairs conference table search committees met. sat edge chairs almost fell forward trying balance n't much concentrating complex question faculty members. constantly breath sweating struggled reach glass water set. could barely walk various sites around campus required tour cases would n't even try. shuffled halls fit escorts waited patiently certainly politely. faculty professional jobs require energy stamina. amount intellect overcome kinds self induced problems discrimination really irrelevant cases one considers terrible burden people impose employers

author: casual observer
post: The employers who hire undocumented workers place a burden upon the society to either condone what they are doing or to act against it. Not doing anything about it results in worse living conditions for all as people who live without the rights and legal protections increase the misery for everyone. California's solution has been to try to be inclusive so that undocumented immigrants function in society mostly like everyone else without formally accepting the undocumented as legal residents but it's sidestepping the issue. The issues are whether California and the U.S. controls the borders and whether it enforces it's laws about immigrant and working in the state remain in no way resolved. Children who identify as Americans but who never were naturalized live in a strange condition which leaves them less than fully enfranchised and legally subject to deportation and unable to act as any another American is entitled. Workers who are being exploited can do little about it unless they can force the employers on their own. We in California have not found an acceptable solution that can be relied upon indefinitely.

post: Too big to fail is just one of the problems in the big banks: there are others, perhaps more troubling, such as "too big to be prosecuted for their crimes", "too wealthy to be told what to do", "too quick to find a loophole to get around any new regulation", "too much political and lobbying power for a corrupt industry to have", "too contemptuous of the law and too interested in their own profit to have scruples about perpetrating massive fraud", "too full of anti-audit strategies to be found out by the auditors until years after the fraud was perpetrated", "too addicted to trading invisible and non-existent money and too contemptuous of actual cash", "too clever for their money laundering schemes to be found out."

author: Zeke27
post: Income is income and should be taxed as the least harmful of all taxes. Eliminate property tax, but tax all income at the same graduated rates. Currently, there is no benefit in savings with interest rates at .3%. Investors should be encouraged to invest in capital projects or improvements, or donate to philanthropic groups by taxing idle income.

author: Jake
post: The ideological undercurrent to this whole debate is whether or not we believe in the government enough to do its job. There should be no question that state institutions should be able to run publicly paid institutions that reflect the public's needs. Fiscal conservatives don't want to limit government, they just want to outsource it. The private sector is interested in profit. The public sector is interested in fulfilling the public's interest. Without it there is no government. There is only a shell whose surface is big smiling millionaires and high paid lobbyists who don't provide any service other than bureaucracy. Bring the idea of government back.

author: Steve from Iowa
post: I would agree that the Division III model makes more sense than Division I or II, but I'd still ask, why is even that much a good use of educational funding? University should be about education. The European model where sports clubs are sponsored by cities or municipalities allows people who want the chance to participate in competitive athletics, at zero cost in distraction to the mission of their universities. That's even better than Division III.

author: patientpatient
post: The argument over punishing overweight people is a classic battle over manipulation and control, as antidemocratic and aristocratic as they come. It presumes that an employer or an insurance company has a right to make a judgment on employees' personal lives, which is every bit as offensive as arguing that the government should do it. We have reached a sorry state in our Calvinist existence when we presume to judge why people look the way they do at what may be a genetic level.

author: Casual Observer
post: Forget the cruise missiles and air strikes without any real full scale attacks which threaten the target country's ability to conduct the egregious acts. All those do is destroy some buildings and kill more bystanders than malefactors. If we participate in any intervention it must be as a part of a significant and broad coalition. So far the U.N. inspectors have not been allowed to inspect. This must be made into a big issue both for Assad's people and for any others who are impeding the inspectors. It is important for the world to know who is doing who to who, here. We must remember that Assad is the leader of a dominant minority, not just some singular tyrant, and bringing him down means exposing that minority to the kinds of sectarian reprisals we saw in Iraq after Saddam was crushed, and that it absorbed our strategic land forces for over five years. That is not the way to go.
